title: 103_hr19
content: The "Medicare Prevention Benefit Act of 1993" includes provisions for annual screening mammography for women over age 64 and coverage of colorectal screening. The amendments for mammography apply to screenings performed on or after January 1, 1994. The Social Security Act is amended to include frequency and payment limits for screening fecal-occult blood tests and screening flexible sigmoidoscopies. Payment limits are set for screening fecal-occult blood tests to not exceed $5 in 1994 and subsequent years. The Social Security Act sets payment limits for screening fecal-occult blood tests not to exceed a certain amount. Additionally, there are frequency limits for these tests, such as not providing the test to individuals under 50 years of age or within 11 months of a previous test. The Secretary establishes payment amounts for screening flexible sigmoidoscopies for early detection of colon cancer, without regard to certain payment limitations. No payment may be made for this screening if provided to an individual for this purpose, subject to revision by the Secretary. The Secretary may review and reduce payment limits for screening fecal-occult blood tests for colon cancer detection, based on appropriateness and estimated requirements. The Secretary, in consultation with the Director of the National Cancer Institute, periodically reviews the frequency for screening fecal-occult blood tests and flexible sigmoidoscopies based on age and other pertinent factors. The Secretary may revise the frequency based on the review findings. The Secretary may revise the frequency of screening tests and procedures under subsection (h)(1) and section 1834(d)(1). Amendments are made to sections 1833(a) and 1833(h)(1)(A) of the Act. Clause (i) and (ii) of section 1848(a)(2)(A) are also amended. The frequency of screening tests and procedures can be revised under subsection (h)(1) and section 1834(d)(1). Amendments are made to sections 1833(a) and 1833(h)(1)(A) of the Act, as well as to clause (i) and (ii) of section 1848(a)(2)(A). U.S.C. 1395w-4(a)(2)(A) and Section 1862(a) of the Act (42 U.S.C. 1395y(a)) are amended to include provisions for screening fecal-occult blood tests and screening flexible sigmoidoscopies for early detection of colon cancer. Effective January 1, 1994, amendments were made to allow screening fecal-occult blood tests and screening flexible sigmoidoscopies under specific sections of the Act. SEC. 4. COVERAGE OF CERTAIN IMMUNIZATIONS. Amendment to the Social Security Act includes adding tetanus-diphtheria booster coverage and its administration. Limitation on frequency of certain immunizations is also addressed. The amendment to the Social Security Act includes adding coverage for tetanus-diphtheria boosters and addressing the limitation on the frequency of certain immunizations. The effective date for these changes is January 1, 1994. The Social Security Act is amended to include coverage for well-child services for individuals under 7 years of age. This includes tetanus-diphtheria boosters and addressing limitations on immunization frequency. Effective date for changes is January 1, 1994. The term 'well-child services' encompasses routine office visits, immunizations, laboratory tests, and preventive dental care for healthy children. The Secretary will establish a periodicity schedule in consultation with relevant entities. Conforming amendments are made to Section 1862(a)(1) of the Social Security Act. The amendments made to Section 1862 of the Social Security Act pertain to well-child services provided more frequently than the established periodicity schedule. Effective from January 1, 1994, these changes include adding a new subparagraph (I) and updating Section 1862(a)(7) to reflect the modifications. SEC. 6. DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS FOR COVERAGE OF OTHER PREVENTIVE SERVICES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish ongoing demonstration projects to provide coverage of preventive services under the medicare program. The projects aim to determine the feasibility of expanding coverage to all individuals enrolled in part B of Medicare and find appropriate delivery methods for these services. The projects will be conducted at sites where the Secretary already runs a demonstration program. The Secretary will establish demonstration projects to cover preventive services under Medicare, including glaucoma and cholesterol screening, osteoporosis treatment, pregnancy services, comprehensive assessments for older individuals, PSA testing, and other services deemed appropriate. The Secretary will conduct demonstration projects for preventive services under Medicare, including glaucoma and cholesterol screening, osteoporosis treatment, pregnancy services, and comprehensive assessments for older individuals. Reports to Congress are required every 2 years, detailing findings and plans for the projects. Appropriations from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund are authorized for the projects, with $4,000,000 allocated for fiscal years 1994 and 1995. The Secretary will conduct demonstration projects for preventive services under Medicare, with appropriations of $4,000,000 for fiscal year 1994, $4,000,000 for fiscal year 1995, $5,000,000 for fiscal year 1996, $5,000,000 for fiscal year 1997, and $6,000,000 for fiscal year 1998. OTA will study the process for reviewing Medicare coverage of preventive services. The Director of the Office of Technology Assessment will conduct a study to develop a process for reviewing Medicare coverage of preventive services, including different evaluation methods and criteria. A report on the study must be submitted to relevant committees within 2 years.
